claim_reports.claim_text: Climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity. Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and Purdue Extension, confirm that human activities, particularly fossil fuel combustion and deforestation, significantly increase greenhouse gas concentrations, which enhance the greenhouse effect and drive global warming.

supports.title: [PDF] Human Activity and the Greenhouse Effect - Purdue Extension
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities are significantly increasing greenhouse gases, which amplifies the natural greenhouse effect and is the primary cause of climate change.
supports.snippet: Every day we generate greenhouse gases through interaction with factories, agriculture, and cars. Our activities produce four major greenhouse gases (Figure 1) ...

supports.title: Are humans causing or contributing to global warming? - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities are significantly increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, which enhances the greenhouse effect and contributes to global warming. It specifically states that the elevated CO2 levels are a direct result of human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels.
supports.snippet: Yes, by increasing the abundance of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, human activities are amplifying Earth's natural greenhouse effect.

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity, detailing how human emissions of carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide have significantly increased since the Industrial Revolution, contributing to global warming.
supports.snippet: Human Activity Is the Cause of Increased Greenhouse Gas Concentrations. Over the last century, burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil has ...

supports.title: What Causes Climate Change? Human and Natural Causes - NRDC
supports.evidence_summary: The article clearly states that human activity, particularly the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation, is the primary driver of climate change, leading to increased greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere. It emphasizes that this anthropogenic influence has drastically altered the climate, resulting in global warming and extreme weather patterns.
supports.snippet: Human-driven causes of climate change: Transportation, Electricity generation, Industry & manufacturing, Agriculture, Oil & gas development, Buildings, ...

claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that the planet's climate is changing, with multiple high-reliability sources indicating significant warming trends, including 2023 being the warmest year on record and a notable increase in global temperatures attributed to human activities.

supports.title: AI predicts Earth's peak warming
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the planet's climate is indeed changing, as 2023 was reported as the warmest year on record, exceeding the 1.5 °C threshold above pre-industrial levels, which is a clear sign of climate change driven by human activities.
supports.snippet: Artificial intelligence provides new evidence that rapid decarbonization will not prevent warming beyond 1.5 degrees Celsius.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the Earth's temperature has risen significantly due to human-induced factors, with a notable increase of 0.26°C per decade over the last decade, confirming that the planet's climate is indeed changing.
supports.snippet: Earth's temperature has risen by an average of 0.11° Fahrenheit (0.06° Celsius) per decade since 1850, or about 2° F in total.

supports.title: Global warming is happening, but not statistically 'surging,' new ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the planet's climate is indeed changing, with observed warming attributed to human activities reaching unprecedented rates, particularly over the last decade.
supports.snippet: Recent years have seen record-breaking temperatures and heat waves globally. Data show 2023 was the warmest year since global records began ...

supports.title: Climate change indicators reached record levels in 2023: WMO
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the planet's climate is changing, as 2023 was reported as the warmest year on record, exceeding previous temperature records and indicating a long-term trend of rising global temperatures driven by man-made global warming.
supports.snippet: The WMO report confirmed that 2023 was the warmest year on record, with the global average near-surface temperature at 1.45 °Celsius.

supports.title: Why record 2023 warming matters even if you don't cover climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the planet's climate is indeed changing, as shown by the record warming of 1.43 °C in 2023, with a significant portion attributed to human activities. The data highlights an unprecedented rate of human-induced warming, reinforcing the claim that the climate is changing.
supports.snippet: The research says on why 2023 was a record warm year and how climate predictions affect a range of news beats, from agriculture to aviation.

claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that sea levels are rising due to thermal expansion and melting polar ice, with significant increases projected for the future. The evidence from the WMO, NASA, and a Nature article collectively support the claim.

supports.title: Future Sea-level Rise Is Certain, but the Amount and Speed Are ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that sea levels are rising due to factors such as thermal expansion of warm ocean water and melting polar ice, driven by human-induced climate change. Projections indicate significant increases in sea levels by 2100, further supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: Global sea-level rise is accelerating: 2024 recorded an increase of 5.9 mm, relative to a mean annual average rate of 3.4 mm/year between 1993– ...

supports.title: NASA Analysis Sees Spike in 2023 Global Sea Level Due to El Niño
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that sea levels are rising due to factors such as thermal expansion of warm ocean water and melting polar ice, with data showing a significant increase in global sea levels from 2022 to 2023.
supports.snippet: Global average sea level rose by about 0.3 inches (0.76 centimeters) from 2022 to 2023, a relatively large jump due mostly to a warming climate ...

supports.title: The rate of global sea level rise doubled during the past three decades
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that sea levels are rising, with the rate of global mean sea level rise increasing from approximately 2.1 mm/year in 1993 to about 4.5 mm/year in 2023, driven by factors such as thermal expansion of warm ocean water and melting polar ice due to climate change.
supports.snippet: The rate of global mean sea level rise over those three decades has increased from ~2.1 mm/year in 1993 to ~4.5 mm/year in 2023.

unclear.evidence_summary: Global average sea level has risen 8-9 inches since 1880, and the rate is accelerating thanks to glacier and ice sheet melt.
unclear.snippet: Global average sea level has risen 8-9 inches since 1880, and the rate is accelerating thanks to glacier and ice sheet melt.

claim_reports.claim_text: A lot of those effects are going to increase with more warming.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the effects of climate change will increase with more warming. Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and NOAA, indicate that rising global temperatures are linked to worsening environmental and ecological impacts, confirming that these effects will intensify with continued greenhouse gas emissions.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that global temperatures are rising and that this increase in temperature is linked to various environmental and ecological processes, suggesting that the effects of climate change will intensify with further warming.
supports.snippet: Earth's temperature has risen by an average of 0.11° Fahrenheit (0.06° Celsius) per decade since 1850, or about 2° F in total.

supports.title: Future Climate Projections - Graphs & Maps
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the effects of climate change are already occurring and are expected to worsen with continued warming, as human emissions of greenhouse gases lead to more extreme weather events and environmental changes.
supports.snippet: Check past, present, and projected future climate conditions related to temperature or precipitation for any county in the United States.

supports.title: The Effects of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the effects of climate change are already occurring and are expected to worsen with continued greenhouse gas emissions, leading to more extreme weather events and environmental changes.
supports.snippet: The potential future effects of global climate change include more frequent wildfires, longer periods of drought in some regions, and an increase in the wind ...

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the effects of climate change are already occurring and will worsen with continued greenhouse gas emissions, confirming that many effects will increase with more warming.
supports.snippet: This latest decadal climate forecast predicts that the central estimate of the 20-year average warming for 2015-2034 will be 1.44°C, (with a 90% ...

supports.title: Climate change impacts - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that global temperatures have been rising significantly, which is linked to various environmental and ecological processes that are affected by this warming. As temperatures increase, the impacts on climate and ecosystems are expected to intensify, supporting the claim that effects will increase with more warming.
supports.snippet: Global temperatures increased. Temperature increased about 2°F (1.1°C) from 1850 to 2023. · Sea level rise has sped up. · Glaciers are shrinking · Arctic sea ice ...

supports.title: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC —
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that global warming is accelerating, with significant increases in temperature and energy in the Earth's system, which suggests that the effects of warming will indeed increase as temperatures rise.
supports.snippet: An IPCC special report on the impacts of global warming of 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels and related global greenhouse gas emission pathways.

claim_reports.claim_text: We develop computer models that help us understand future climate change.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that computer models are developed to accurately project future climate change, demonstrating their role in understanding climate dynamics. Notably, the NOAA Climate.gov and the Center for Science Education highlight the established physical processes behind these models, reinforcing the claim.

supports.title: Basics of Global Climate Models
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how climate models are developed to provide accurate projections of future climate change, confirming the claim that computer models help us understand future climate change.
supports.snippet: Climate models are computer programs that consist of several hundred thousand lines of code. Each model is created by a modeling group, which consists of many ...

supports.title: Climate Models | NOAA Climate.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The snippet indicates that climate models are based on established physical processes, which suggests they are used to simulate and understand future climate change.
supports.snippet: Climate models are based on well-documented physical processes to simulate the transfer of energy and materials through the climate system.

supports.title: Predictions of Future Global Climate | Center for Science Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how climate models have been developed and improved over decades to provide accurate projections of future climate change based on various scenarios of greenhouse gas emissions.
supports.snippet: Climate models predict that Earth's global average temperature will rise an additional 4° C (7.2° F) during the 21st Century if greenhouse gas levels continue ...

supports.title: High-resolution climate model forecasts a wet, turbulent future
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how climate models have accurately predicted global warming and how current models are advanced, incorporating extensive data to project future climate scenarios. This supports the claim that computer models help understand future climate change.
supports.snippet: That fidelity in reproducing the past gives MESACLIP scientists more confidence in the model's future predictions—and some of them are alarming.

A 2023 report highlighted a record number of billion-dollar weather disasters, including heatwaves and wildfires, while NASA confirmed a rise in extreme weather events due to climate change.

supports.snippet: There were 28 weather and climate disasters in 2023, surpassing the previous record of 22 in 2020, tallying a price tag of at least $92.9 billion.

claim_reports.claim_text: We are developing technologies that can help us limit future warming.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that technologies are being developed to limit future warming, particularly through innovative solutions like Carbon Capture Utilisation and Storage (CCUS), lab-grown meat, and nuclear power, as highlighted by the Climate Action Tracker and Earth.Org.

supports.title: Emissions pathways to 2100 - Climate Action Tracker
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses various innovative technologies, such as Carbon Capture Utilisation and Storage (CCUS), lab-grown meat, and nuclear power, that can help limit future warming by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and actively removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: The CAT determines a 1.5°C compatible benchmark using pathways from the IPCC AR6 pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C with no or low overshoot, ...

supports.title: 4 Emerging Technologies to Fight Climate Change | Earth.Org
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses various emerging technologies, such as Carbon Capture Utilisation and Storage (CCUS), lab-grown meat, and nuclear power, that are being developed to help limit future warming and combat climate change.
supports.snippet: Blockchain, artificial intelligence, quantum computing, robotics are key emerging technologies in the fight against climate change.

transcript_data.text: Why does climate change matter? NASA We Asked a NASA Scientist. Well, it's happening. We look at the Earth from space and we measure it on the ground. And what we see is that the planet's climate is changing. The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began. It's serious. Even a little change in temperature can have big effects. And we're seeing some of those effects now. Sea levels are rising. We're seeing more extreme events like heatwaves and heavy rainfall and wildfire. And we know that a lot of those effects are going to increase with more warming. These changes are impacting decisions that some people make every day, like a farmer thinking about what crops to grow or a homeowner thinking about flood risk. But there's hope. There are scientists at NASA and around the world that are researching this. We know more about our planet than we have ever before, and we learn more every day. So we know why climate is changing. We know that it's due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity. We also have tools that can help us better understand and better prepare for future climate change. So we develop computer models that help us understand how much it might change in the future. And we're also developing technologies here at NASA and around the world that can help us limit future warming or respond to the warming that we're experiencing. So why does climate change matter? It's real. It's serious, and it's here. We Asked a NASA Scientist. NASA. A NASA 360 Production.
